reviewText: The gameplay concept might be interesting with some iteration and some work, but wow, this is a bad game right now. The graphics look like a bad Doom map from the mid 90s. Low res textures, low poly models, horrible lighting. Enemies look look plastic and ridiculous, not especially scary. Wierd invisible walls in the single layout that passes for each level.\n\nThis looks like an afternoon project by a middle schooler. Executed on by someone who gave a damn, this could be an interesting gameplay mechanic in an interesting, compelling game but this is not it.

reviewText: Intro was nice, went downhill quickly from there. Not scary at all, only saw one monster type and most corpses were duplicates. Biggest problem is rooms are far too small. Pickup a note, kill a dude and move to next level. As another user mentioned, design-wise it looks like something straight out of the 90s. Can't say I would recommend the game without a price drop or some kind of overhaul, just feels lazy.\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ctGRKQ5ecjQ

reviewText:
Do you want a game where you climb up some building floor by floor by grabbing keys to open doors trying to escape some weird fish squid monsters while you bleed out and your only defense is the spraying blood of your open wound? Neither did I.

It took just over 30 minutes to complete after getting stuck in walls and objects multiple times and having to slowly kill myself by stabbing my arm with a screwdriver repeatedly. Very boring. The only positive I can give this game is the opening intro.

Terrible game. Glad I got it from an old Greenlight bundle. This isn't even worth the current discount price of £4.19, £0.19 sounds about right.

reviewText:
Bleeding Borders, developed by Curse Box Studios, is a survival horror game with a really cool premise. But… it’s ♥♥♥♥ing broken.

You’ll be playing as Zoey, a run-of-the-mill survivalist living in a post-apocalyptic world ravished by rubbery, fleshy monsters called the Pale Ones. After a scavenging trip goes awry, Zoey’s fellow survivors are slaughtered by Pale Ones. She just barely manages to escape before losing her arm to a monster. Although, in the brutal process, she learns that her blood is somehow capable of poisoning the beasts. (I’d tell you why that is… but I failed to beat this poor excuse for a game.)

Anyway, your goal is to reach the roof of the dilapidated office building and ride the cabal car back to safety.

Now, I’d first like to commend the concept this game has created. Using a rusty screw driver, the player must stab Zoey’s gaping wound and spray incoming monsters with blood to kill them. Really cool idea, but this game’s disgusting design, disgusting optimization, and disgusting character models ruin what might’ve been a decent horror experience.

There really isn’t anything else to this title. You’ll walk up floor by floor, slaying the odd monster, reading notes and picking up keys. Oh, and by the way, these notes are everywhere, and I mean EVERYWHERE. But trust me… it won’t be long before any sane person ignores them all together; trying to read while stomaching this game’s frame rate is as plausible as Donald Trump winning the 2016 election.

Oh yeah, did I mention the frame rate? It’s like something straight out of hell. My rig is nothing to brag about, in fact, it’s kinda ♥♥♥♥, but Jesus… COD: Ghosts had better optimization than this.

This game crashed on me three times, and one of those crashes managed to freeze up my entire computer. I couldn’t get halfway through this crap before succumbing to my migraine and quitting entirely.

Just do yourself a favor: Stay far, far away.

reviewText:
Absolute garbage.

There are no video options. None. That makes ZERO sense. And no customizable controls and no mouse sensitivity options. The mouse sensitivity is flat out terrible.

The gameplay is very wonky and the enemies are horrid. Too many bugs and their pathways are too bugged and slow.

I cannot stand the sounds in this game because they are so bad. There is no story too.

I am a huge horror junkie and this game, in my book, is one of the worst horror games ever made. Ever.

Plain garbage. DO NOT BUY.

1 out of 10

reviewText:
You'd have to say that the premise of Bleeding Border is pretty novel; you lose half your forearm before the game even begins and are forced to ascend a twelve storey office block to escape the monsters that dwell within it and a gradually fatal loss of blood. Your only weapon against the tentacled beasts that hunt you is your own vital fluids which you spray from your sketchily bandaged stump by jamming a screwdriver in the wound hole.
Then again, it's pretty novel for a reason. Why would a species so dramatically allergic to human blood EAT PEOPLE? How are there any of these imbeciles left in the first place?
I'd be willing to lay that to one side if the game itself were any good but, for a title that sees you trying to flee to a rooftop cable car before you wring yourself dry out of your mangled arm, it's a tediously placid experience. There's no urgency in your situation. You'll find more medipacks than you'll ever need. There are notes, NOTES for god's sake, like I'm going to stop to check them out mere minutes after my hand's been chewed off, and the monsters just kind of slowly amble towards you, giving you plenty of time to douse them in artery juice. Once you get over the amusing gruesomeness of this sole attack, it's a wildly annoying six second animation that will unavoidably cause you to take damage before you can kill your opponent.
At around 25 minutes long, the only positive you can take from this mess is that it's a surefire refund candidate.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L6f_6Lb7bIU

reviewText:
Well, I have to admit, I stopped at level 10. The abysimal performance, horrid  movement and terrible invisible walls did me in. Died, and just couldn't get myself to get through the horrid experience again of navigating that level.

You ascend a tower with identical ugly layout every single level. You fight a single-monster, although on higher levels it's texture is replaced by a completely yellow one(?) as it spawns in your face (literally) rather than walk about... oh jolly. Oh did I say walk about, I meant slide along the floor of course, my bad.

You fight foes by stabbing yourself and getting your blood over them, then frantically need to look for a medpack to cure your bloodloss. This restoring goes ridicilously slow so be prepared to AFK for a minute or so everytime. Oddly enough a giant hook on enemies hitting you doesn't cause bloodloss though like a screwdriver does. What?
Also odd is that your blood is toxic to them but if they hit you with their blade, and obviously make you bleed, that's just fine and dandy.

Also, let's forget you find a freaking shotgun on level 2 or 3, but hey, let's just stab yourself and bleed out instead.

And so every level resorts into find foe, kill foe, find medpack, use medpack, find key, use key, repeat 12x. All the while going at what feels 10FPS. You can also find notes to read but OH GOD THE ENGRISH. Not to mention the game doesn't pause so generally you bleed out trying to actually read them. The developer obviously stopped bothering with them aswell since you will find the same note multiple times on different levels.

reviewText: Let's get the bad out of the way, first: The game's in the running for the absolute ugliest I've ever seen. It's blatantly unfinished, with two out of three game modes to be added later. There's a few nasty glitches, though no longer anything game breaking.\n\nI still have to recommend this as one of the best horror games I've played. Beyond just having some legitimately creepy monster designs, it just has an incredibly effective central mechanic that ratchets up the tension. You're in an abandoned building, filled with monsters. The good news is that you have a 100% effective weapon against them. The bad news is that it's your blood -- every time you try to kill an enemy, you inflict a bleeding wound on yourself and need bandages or you'll eventually bleed out and die. The game becomes an exercise in avoiding combat where possible, and where forced to, it frequently becomes a tense race for the next medkit before you become too far gone and either collapse or get easily picked off by one of the monsters. I've rarely played a game that left me with as much dread and fear as this one did.

reviewText:
i'd enjoy this and cant wait for any new updates, i havent played much of it so far. only up to the water level who it started to lag my game, but it wasnt all that bad i was still ablee to  get pass it but i stopped playing it aftert that. i liked how the team came up with the idea of using your own blood to hurt/kill the monsters, though it was hard trying to pick if i should fight, run or use my last medic but it was fun. unlike other horroir game where all you have to do is just lose line of sight, runing and hiding should be your last idea becuse these monsters will kill you before you can take to steps back.

i can tell this game is still vary new (the graphics isnt the best and they could do a bit more with each level/floor looks) but i have a good feeling about this and can't wait to see what the developers could do to make this game better.

all i can hope they can add to this game is a way for you to throw like a rock or something so you can sneek pass the monster when you haave low heath.

reviewText:
I got this game on Sale and it was worth it.
Although the graphics aren't top notch they're functional and the gameplay where you're only able to defend yourself inflicting damage to yourself makes it quite interesting.
The ambience is quite nice and got a few jumpscares out of it.
Even though there are a lot of things to polish in this game I found it to be quite entertaining and definitely worth my time and money, specially considering that the devs seem to be active in updating it, so hopefully, those details to be polished will eventually be worked on.
In conclusion. Positive.

reviewText:
Bleeding Border may come off a bit rough on the edges, but there is a joy to be found in exploring an old school survival horror game, with its strengths and weaknesses. The price is just right for a compact and intense gameplay experience.

Give this game a chance and you'll experience a dejavu to the 90's way of game design, with a new and interesting gameplay twist.

7.5/10
